newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian national coal strike averted.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian national coal strike averted.

text.p: A threatened national coal strike in Australia has been averted following a rescue package allowing for production to resume at the financially-shaken Metropolitan Colliery Ltd on the south coast of New South Wales.
A spokesman for the Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union (CFMEU) told Reuters that threats of a national strike had been dropped after the mine had been put back into production.
Work re-started at the mine this week. It was closed and put in the hands of an administrator in November last year after it was hit by a geologically-caused disruption to production.
The national coal strike was threatened unless sacked mine workers were paid entitlements of A$4.9 million, which Metropolitan Colliery said it could not afford.

A solution was reached when the mine's 10 percent shareholder, Kanematsu Corp of Japan, assented to a plan brokered by mine administrator Price Waterhouse, the New South Wales state government and the CFMEU.
Kanematsu is a secured creditor for A$20 million.

The plan involves the mine being operated on behalf of the administrator by contract miner Colrock Australia Pty Ltd, while the state government funded outstanding entitlements of more than A$1 million.
The mine's administrator has projected saleable coal production of about 850,000 tonnes in 1997, expected to be sold at a minimum average of A$45.00 a tonne.

Ian Ferres, chairman of Denehurst Ltd, which owns 90 percent of Metropolitan and is a second-ranking fixed charge holder, told Reuters that the deal and the resumption of mining had put his company in a better position because the mine could
be sold for more as a going concern.
"The administrator's next task is to attempt to sell the mine to someone else and obviously while it's working you're more likely to get a better price for it," he said.
Denehurst, meanwhile, continues with its other activities of copper and base metals mining, he said.
